and i use that phrase deliberately - becomes an all consuming obsession clearly she's got psychological problems and yet like so many paedophiles she's very clever at manipulating people and circumstances to her best advantage poor jack is her target at the start of the novel and slowly she lures him in they quickly become sexually active and she's has a stroke of luck when he discloses he lives with his father and he's at work often after school so they have the house to themselves of course they have a time when they're almost caught and celeste begins a very strange time where she convinces jack father that she's his girlfriend and that allows her to spend even more time there jack is convinced they're in love and will marry when he's eighteen i feel so so sorry for him of course things go wrong jack moves away and celeste picks up a new victim jack is able to return periodically so she's using both boys without the other knowing its a real study in how carefully child groomers work to seduce and convince kids they are wanted and loved and that everything is done consensually when of course in reality they don't have the full story or the maturity to see they are just being used sadly its a sharp look at life when all falls apart and celeste is caught everyone is shocked at she's such a model teacher good looking wife etc - its as if we only think of child molesters as sleezy grubby easily recognized characters when in reality they can be anyone even in her teaching lessons she obsesses about sex talking about romeo and juliet lord of the flies etc and bringing the sexual side in she uses essays to discover what attracts her chosen boy to females so she can emulate their choice the kids love her as they see her as one of them and that's one of the dangers because she does well with them the other teachers assume all is well its a sharp reminder we need to look beyond the surface of people and see what they are really doing at her trial there a part which mad me really sad a bad reflection of society and yet very very true her solicitor pushes the jury towards the view that 14 year old boys are ruled by their hormones and that they made advances to her and that most kids and adult men would envy them being sexually active with such a good looking young woman i can see that as an argument used in reality we're shocked at girls being groomed and yet a boy groomed by an attractive lady - its "whoa good for you mate " kind of attitude we need to change that quickly alissa goes on to show us a bit about how badly affected the boys are - especially jack who threw his emotions whole heartedly in and now has guilt feelings about what happened including his part in what happened with his father its something that would be hard to recover from and if it were real i think he'd need a great deal of help to get past it it left me wondering what made celeste this way someone doesn't suddenly turn to kids for sex there must have been some indications somewhere before it got this far something that happened to her maybe abusers are often abuse victims themselves sadly we also see how lightly she gets off at the end imo anyway and how all the restrictions on keeping her from schools etc doesn't stop her getting in contact with more kids for sex its a sad story really well written and realistic its not one i'd re read but was incredibly moving thinking about what went on why she was as she was what would happen to the boys after and why the trial went as it did i could relate it easily to a real event everything was so carefully written and full of realism it felt like reading a factual tale of something that had happened it left me feeling sad for all of them all those affected the boys and their families and even celeste in a way as though she was caught she didn't get the help she clearly needed and went on with her sad and dangerous obsession stars its rare i give full stars for a book i'll only read once but this one deserves it so five it is

raw_text.1489: sigh i don't know how to begin this review tampa is the kind of book that could've been stellar because the premise in itself was extremely disturbing it could've been the perfect avenue to discuss less talked about issues like pedophilia and lust verging on obsession now the question is this did tampa succeed in making a powerful message about double standards and the horror of pedophilia by being a sophisticated work of literature the answer for me is no you know i understand what other reviews were saying that celeste the beautiful 26 year old teacher had to be a monster in order to strike a strong message in the mind of readers that even women are capable of so much more than what the society thinks of them and if you're wondering if the author wasn't afraid to get there i'd say yes she succeeded in crafting a monster who's too caught up in her sexual fantasies about teenage boys celeste's actions were quite extreme and she never held back in narrating every bit of sexual act she does on jack the author crafts very detailed sex scenes to the point where you'd feel disgusted yourself by seeing how jack the fourteen year old guy was obviously used and objectified for her own selfish purposes i'd say the author also succeeded in crafting a believable 14 year old guy whose curiosity is at its peak when it comes to the nature of sex but this horrific portrayal of sex and the protagonist's sick fetish is its ultimate downfall sadly celeste is a one dimensional character and she came across as nothing more than a monster i believe all human beings are complex by nature even the most stereotypical people have depth hidden inside them this is where the author failed in my opinion because even the sickest monsters have complexity and human emotions celeste never had other visible human traits or thoughts besides her lust which made her a caricature of the female sexual predator void of complexity it's not just that i appreciate honest depictions of sex if it provides a specific purpose in the story the numerous sex scenes in tampa though verged on erotica with its over detailed narration of oral sex and semen spills to the point where it no longer served a purpose i agree with tatiana's review that there's a very fine line between honest transgressive literature and erotica sadly tampa crossed that line and its intended message of showing double standard got blurred along the story with all the details about oral sex and sexual positions the use of language was also overblown and in the end it became a bloated mess of purple prose in short tampa had the potential to become a a sophisticated piece of literature but there was a lack of skill on the author's part in handling such a sensitive topic the sex scenes raw_text.1524: blogged at river city reading alissa nutting's forthcoming novel centers on celeste price a first year teacher with an intense sexual obsession with young teenage boys with eerie precision celeste aligns each piece of her life to meet her sexual demands she is well provided for by her wealthy husband and able to take a job teaching eighth grade english to scout potential prey as the school year progresses she lures her student jack into a secret relationship inching closer to exposure each day i could hear the teacher verse exploding from the moment i heard tampa discussed on the bookrageous podcast in general we teachers tend to be uproariously opposed to anything that paints us in a bad light can you imagine what the general consensus will be just from reading the blurb unfortunately i fear that's where many teachers will stop despite the fact that they may remain caught up in the discussion i figured if i was going to have a real opinion of the novel i should probably read it there is no doubt from the first page of tampa that celeste price is on the far side of sanity with nutting shouting her perversions loud and clear even readers well traveled in the smutosphere may find themselves shocked and appalled it takes a jarring disturbing what the hell am i reading first few chapters to accept the fact that celeste's blunt descriptions of her intentions and actions are not going anywhere at this point readers can begin to appreciate nutting's devotion to her character from beginning to end celeste's vain predatory one track mind never wavers while it is something no one is comfortable with nutting's ability to crawl inside celeste's mind and pick apart her thoughts on not only teenagers but her husband and co workers is spot on and often brilliantly funny i think it was wise of nutting to forego a backstory for celeste though it left her feeling somewhat one dimensional at times had readers known her family history or the path she took to her compulsions nutting would have opened the door for debate over the causes of pedophilia and might have distracted from the novel as a whole in the end tampa is a daring well written book willing to push boundaries and spark conversation while it will surely leave readers feeling uncomfortable it may also leave them feeling surprised by the change in a sometimes monotonic reading atmosphere

raw_text.1577: in 2006 debra lafave a teacher from florida was the centre of a media storm when she found herself in court for sleeping with a 14 year old student but was granted probation part of the final judgement being based upon her being 'too pretty for prison' the court case which caused widespread outrage forms the subject for nutting's blistering satirical debut celeste price nutting's protagonist follows the same path in tampa the discomfortingly attached first person narrative forces the reader to share every passionately lascivious and nauseatingly detached sexual encounter celeste grinds and thrusts her way through it is this attachment to the narrator which has drawn comparison to nabakov's infamously unreliable narrator humbert humbert however unlike in nabakov's lolita nutting employs an unflinching gaze from the selfish celeste never allowing her audience to see the events unfold from the mind of any other than her sexual sociopath not only challenging notions of what a paedophile and sexual predator looks like and how leniency can still be given in the most seemingly clear cut of criminal depravities nutting's narrative by treading largely untested waters of the sexualisation of young boys in a world that has often become commonplace to accept of young girls challenges how the question of gender inequality affects an area so rarely encountered celeste is unabashed in her seductions revelling in the attraction she elicits from young boys which she and the rest of society view as both natural and deserved nutting compels the reader to question societal attitudes towards the public nature of women's bodies by emphasising the fragility of the line between desire and action with celeste only crossing that line at the start of her torrid affair by exploring these areas nutting stimulates both disgust and fascination in equal measure as the reader becomes a second compliant victim to that of the 14 year old jack patrick defying characterisation by its ambiguous perspective and unprecedented subject matter tampa is as divisive as it is important in an age where public moralising about paedophilia is both consistent and widespread the chasms of moral space which are left for the reader to fill left by the jumpy memories of its amoral protagonist make tampa an intriguing novel ripe for intense literary analysis and debate

debut novel of the year the basics twenty six year old celeste price is eager to start her new job teaching middle school in suburban tampa her reason access to fourteen year old boys the only people to whom she is sexually attracted my thoughts as i was raving about this novel to my husband shortly after i finished it he somewhat jokingly said that i really enjoy novels about sexual deviance stumped i asked him for other examples and he promptly replied room which he was too disturbed by to finish and i call one of my all time favorite reads later i realized i also adored repeat it today with tears my review which is about a father daughter love affair it's true all of these novels share the theme of sexual deviance but they're also about so much more than that which is why i truly love them i read fiction for many reasons but one of them is to better understand other people when news breaks of a teacher having an affair with a young student the question of how or why a person could do that is often asked while the question may be meant rhetorically i love that nutting embraces the character of the celeste in an attempt to provide a more complicated answer to the question nutting does not hold back celeste is a brutally honest narrator and while some parts of this novel were challenging to read the novel is better because of them there are moments when celeste's relationship with jack seem almost normal i loved these moments precisely because they soon seem so very wrong it's a testament to nutting's writing character development and world building that there could be moments of eroticism in such a taboo relationship because celeste is the reader's window into this world it's easy to be swept away with how she sees the events but it's still difficult to pages of her story are the truly perfect ending the verdict tampa is a novel that reminds me why i will always love fiction best alissa nutting masterfully gets inside the mind and body of celeste the and delight at the unputdownable quality this book offers to its readers its racy narrative with subtle undertones of social commentary marks the entry of debatable questions one can raise with the backdrop of this hypocritical society we're a reluctant part of how our argument about various forbidden subjects is governed around the elements involved in the execution of such immoral acts is highlighted with a dash of odiousness in tampa "people who look like me don't go to jail "celeste is fully aware of her strengths and also about the loopholes in her usual foolproof plans to keep the dark side of her life run smoothly in this way she comes across as an unflinchingly shrewd and selfish person which is not a big deal to think about but to convincingly put it on paper is a commendable feat nutting's voice is fresh and uninhibited but she falters towards the end the climax appears to be written in a rushed manner and struggles to find a strong base to stand on amidst some superficial factors forced upon it moreover the explicitness of sex scenes could have mellowed down a bit in order to reach albeit shocking but an acceptable level of reality since in some instances the line of fantasy is stretched too far considering the involvement of teenage boys or is it just another trick on part of our unreliable narrator apart from this it's a fairly decent no oxymoron w r t book's content intended and quick read which doesn't purport to be a literary masterpiece but an ordinary fiction based on the confessions of a dangerous mind

raw_text.1947: alissa nutting is no nabokov but her writing is reminiscent of him in all the right ways highly embellished bitterly satirical and unnervingly floral in its depiction of dark sinister ugly shit when i started tampa i thought that it was merely lolita esque but around the halfway point i realized that it's in fact a proper retelling i'm a sucker for the gender reversed retelling so in some ways i think i was destined to love this book but i also have to hand it to nutting she created the perfect cocktail of a narrative that is so deeply unsettling but also impossible to stop reading i browsed the existing goodreads reviews for this book and most of them are predictably to the effect of eww and yeah to be fair this book definitely invokes a big ol' sloppy eww if you can't suspend the limitations of your own sexual identity long enough to imagine that celeste price could be a real human this is probably not the right novel for you but my take on this book is that it's no more about lusting after teenagers than it is about inhabiting a body that society reads as immaculate and without volition when you're racked with your own aberrations and vulgarity most of us never experience that vulgarity on the same pathological level that celeste does but what woman can't relate to the experience of feeling like your entire sexual appetite replete with neuroses and complexes and kink is erased by your womanness in particular i loved this passage i found that sometimes it was a relief to do something unattractive in private to confirm that i'm deeply flawed when so many others imagine me to be perfect people are often startled by my handwriting because i'm pretty they assume everything i do is pretty

raw_text.1984: i read tampa over a few visits to powell's leaning against a bookshelf or over a cup of coffee at fresh pot the book might have escaped my radar but it was featured on a prominent shelf and my hometown was emblazoned across the cover and when i read the dust jacket blurb i thought oh boy because just what tampa florida needs is more controversy and notoriety i read the first few chapters while my boyfriend's visiting mom browsed the catholic section looking for a book about the saints i was a little underwhelmed by the writing but i was amused to think that i was reading such awkward phrases as an excited loop of hushed masturbation while a couple of rooms away she was reading about the apostles celeste price's is an interesting story i'm curious about the amount of research ms nutting did whether her concise planning and methodical approach is truly representative of that of someone with celeste's predilection the book is certainly a quick read it moves along and celeste's deviousness and the openness with which she outlines her desires and plans is sort of shocking and certainly sensational the ending with its recounting of the attendant media circus and different legal punishments for pretty white chicks rang true however the climactic scene which led to the overly abbreviated ending seemed a little over the top i don't know that the second boy needed even to have been introduced though i suppose that's what allowed for celeste's downfall tampa isn't a book i would pay the list price for but overall i enjoyed it in the same guilty pleasure slightly trashy way i devoured gone girl last year

raw_text.2002: why is this book necessary is the world a better place because this book exists it would have been one thing if the book had explored the general phenomenon of teachers and others in position of power taking advantage of their status to prey on young minds and bodies it would have been interesting if the main character had been cast in a more sympathetic light so the reader felt conflict between disgust and pity but in this book celeste is such a monstrous caricature of a pedophile it's hard to feel anything at all about her but revulsion any sympathy for her goes out the window at the very beginning of the book when she writes on students' desks using vaginal fluid and shoves the written name of a favorite teenager inside her body while her extremity made the book a page turner it didn't make for a very realistic or cathartic read celeste's only real character trait was her perversion which made her fascinating to read about but not to analyze i prefer my antihero protagonists to have more depth more facets and she was all beastly urges and manipulation this book won't make me look at real cases of teachers becoming abusers any differently than i would have before and i feel that's a failing on the novel's part that said i feel obligated to give this book a three because i couldn't put it down i don't think i've read 250 pages in just over 24 hours since my harry potter days but the book gets points off for a main character who suffered from a lack of complexity and for purple prose i don't know if the intention was for the book to read like a harlequin novel or if the author is simply fond of adjectives it is a literary choice especially since it juxtaposes the adult language with the disturbing relationship at the heart of the novel but it's not a literary choice i particularly enjoy no one talks like that
